elements.content: A new type of click reaction, sulfur­(VI) fluoride exchange (SuFEx), has been utilized to prepare five postsynthetically modified UiO-67 series metal–organic frameworks (MOFs). The postsynthetic modification (PSM) via SuFEx can be achieved selectively for the sulfonyl fluoride (R-SO2F) without degrading the MOF structure as confirmed by X-ray crystallographic analysis. The present SuFEx method provides a straightforward tool for introducing new functionality inside MOFs. Introduction of an imidazolium group into the MOF afforded a heterogeneous catalyst for the benzoin condensation reaction.
elements.clean_text: A new type of click reaction, sulfur(VI) fluoride exchange (SuFEx), has been utilized to prepare five postsynthetically modified UiO-67 series metal-organic frameworks (MOFs). The postsynthetic modification (PSM) via SuFEx can be achieved selectively for the sulfonyl fluoride (R-SO2F) without degrading the MOF structure as confirmed by X-ray crystallographic analysis. The present SuFEx method provides a straightforward tool for introducing new functionality inside MOFs. Introduction of an imidazolium group into the MOF afforded a heterogeneous catalyst for the benzoin condensation reaction.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are representative porous crystalline materials consisting of metals and organic linkers. As the interest in applications of MOFs such as gas storage and separation, sensing, electrical conductivity, and catalysis has increased, the efficient introduction of desired functionality into MOFs has received much attention to afford MOFs with improved properties. Among the MOF functionalization methods, postsynthetic modification (PSM) has received the spotlight as an elegant functionalization method. The introduction of functional groups in MOF, which had many limitations with existing direct synthesis, could be easily made possible by PSMs. PSMs developed by Lee, Kim, Cohen, Yaghi, and many other researchers enable existing MOFs to be applied to numerous applications by functionalization of the open frameworks. Recently, the postsynthetically modified MOFs with biomolecules were also applied as a platform to donate enzyme-like complexity.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are representative porous crystalline materials consisting of metals and organic linkers. As the interest in applications of MOFs such as gas storage and separation, sensing, electrical conductivity, and catalysis has increased, the efficient introduction of desired functionality into MOFs has received much attention to afford MOFs with improved properties. Among the MOF functionalization methods, postsynthetic modification (PSM) has received the spotlight as an elegant functionalization method. The introduction of functional groups in MOF, which had many limitations with existing direct synthesis, could be easily made possible by PSMs. PSMs developed by Lee, Kim, Cohen, Yaghi, and many other researchers enable existing MOFs to be applied to numerous applications by functionalization of the open frameworks. Recently, the postsynthetically modified MOFs with biomolecules were also applied as a platform to donate enzyme-like complexity.

elements.content: For versatile applicability of these methods, the copper­(I)-catalyzed azide–alkyne cycloaddition reaction (CuAAC), the archetypal “click reaction”, has been applied to the functionalization of MOFs. After synthesis of azide- or alkyne-functionalized MOFs, the counterparts of the alkyne or azide substrates are introduced into the MOFs via CuAAC. This approach has been further developed for one-pot two-step click reaction based on the amine-to-azide transformation of amine-MOFs. Nevertheless, due to the potential concern of the remained Cu­(I) catalyst in modified MOFs by CuAAC, the Cu­(I)-free PSMs of MOFs were also attempted to overcome the contamination problem, such as strained-promoted click reaction using cyclooctyne substrates, coordinated azide–alkyne click reaction of Mn-MOFs, and 1,3-dipolar nitrile oxide-alkyne cycloaddition.
elements.clean_text: For versatile applicability of these methods, the copper(I)-catalyzed azide-alkyne cycloaddition reaction (CuAAC), the archetypal "click reaction", has been applied to the functionalization of MOFs. After synthesis of azide- or alkyne-functionalized MOFs, the counterparts of the alkyne or azide substrates are introduced into the MOFs via CuAAC. This approach has been further developed for one-pot two-step click reaction based on the amine-to-azide transformation of amine-MOFs. Nevertheless, due to the potential concern of the remained Cu(I) catalyst in modified MOFs by CuAAC, the Cu(I)-free PSMs of MOFs were also attempted to overcome the contamination problem, such as strained-promoted click reaction using cyclooctyne substrates, coordinated azide-alkyne click reaction of Mn-MOFs, and 1,3-dipolar nitrile oxide-alkyne cycloaddition.

elements.content: Herein, we report a new PSM strategy based on the newly developed “sulfur­(VI) fluoride exchange (SuFEx)″ by Sharpless et al. SuFEx is a new generation of click reaction that substitutes a fluorine atom with a desirable functional group by the aid of the strong Si–F bond when the functional group with tert-butyldimethylsilyl (TBDMS)-ether or TBDMS-amine is treated in the presence of R–SO2F (). This reaction can be carried out with catalysts such as 1,8-diazabicyclo[5.4.0]­undec-7-ene (DBU) or bifluoride salts. This method has several advantages: (a) The S­(VI)–F bond is stable (80–90 kcal/mol) under typical oxidation or high temperature (up to 230 °C) conditions, (b) the only byproduct, highly stable silyl fluoride can be easily removed by simple washing or vaporization, and (c) the sulfonyl fluoride and silyl substrates used in the reaction are easily prepared compared with other clickable functional groups such as azide and alkyne groups. We have successfully synthesized UiO-67-SO 2 F (1) from a sulfonyl fluoride linker; to the best of our knowledge, this is the first time it has been prepared. Furthermore, the postsynthetic modification of 1 using five trimethylsilyl (TMS)-ether and TMS-amine substrates has been successfully demonstrated without any catalyst, even in the crystalline products with full characterization by single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we report a new PSM strategy based on the newly developed "sulfur(VI) fluoride exchange (SuFEx)" by Sharpless et al. SuFEx is a new generation of click reaction that substitutes a fluorine atom with a desirable functional group by the aid of the strong Si-F bond when the functional group with tert-butyldimethylsilyl (TBDMS)-ether or TBDMS-amine is treated in the presence of R-SO2F (). This reaction can be carried out with catalysts such as 1,8-diazabicyclo[5.4.0]undec-7-ene (DBU) or bifluoride salts. This method has several advantages: (a) The S(VI)-F bond is stable (80-90 kcal/mol) under typical oxidation or high temperature (up to 230 °C) conditions, (b) the only byproduct, highly stable silyl fluoride can be easily removed by simple washing or vaporization, and (c) the sulfonyl fluoride and silyl substrates used in the reaction are easily prepared compared with other clickable functional groups such as azide and alkyne groups. We have successfully synthesized UiO-67-SO  2  F (1) from a sulfonyl fluoride linker; to the best of our knowledge, this is the first time it has been prepared. Furthermore, the postsynthetic modification of 1 using five trimethylsilyl (TMS)-ether and TMS-amine substrates has been successfully demonstrated without any catalyst, even in the crystalline products with full characterization by single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis.

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<caption>
<title>Sulfur­(VI) Fluoride Exchange (SuFEx)
Reactions</title>
</caption>
<graphic id="gr1" position="float" xlink:href="am-2018-14065j_0005.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

On the basis of the method developed by Sharpless et al., the sulfonyl fluoride ligand (2-(fluorosulfonyl)-[1,1′-biphenyl]-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid, L-SO 2 F; ) was prepared by the fluorination of 4,4′-dimethyl-1,1′-biphenyl-2-sulfonyl chloride with KHF2 in biphasic THF/H2O solution, followed by the oxidation of the methyl group of biphenyl using CrO3 in acetic acid (see the Supporting Information). Consistent with the previous results, it was confirmed that the SO2F group was stable even under the strong acidic and oxidative conditions. To secure the high thermal and chemical stability of MOF, we have synthesized the zirconium-based MOF (UiO-67), as PSM of UiO series has been extensively studied for the past decade. Using the well-known additive effect of benzoic acid, 1 was successfully prepared as octahedron-shaped crystals by the solvothermal reaction of ZrCl4, L-SO2F, and benzoic acid in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) at 120 °C for 48 h (). The structure of 1 was confirmed by a single crystal X-ray diffraction (SXRD) study. 1, which crystallized in Fm3̅m space group, consists of tetrahedral and octahedral cages with an fcu topology ().
elements.clean_text: On the basis of the method developed by Sharpless et al., the sulfonyl fluoride ligand (2-(fluorosulfonyl)-[1,1'-biphenyl]-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid, L-SO  2  F; ) was prepared by the fluorination of 4,4'-dimethyl-1,1'-biphenyl-2-sulfonyl chloride with KHF2 in biphasic THF/H2O solution, followed by the oxidation of the methyl group of biphenyl using CrO3 in acetic acid (see the Supporting Information). Consistent with the previous results, it was confirmed that the SO2F group was stable even under the strong acidic and oxidative conditions. To secure the high thermal and chemical stability of MOF, we have synthesized the zirconium-based MOF (UiO-67), as PSM of UiO series has been extensively studied for the past decade. Using the well-known additive effect of benzoic acid, 1 was successfully prepared as octahedron-shaped crystals by the solvothermal reaction of ZrCl4, L-SO2F, and benzoic acid in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) at 120 °C for 48 h (). The structure of 1 was confirmed by a single crystal X-ray diffraction (SXRD) study. 1, which crystallized in Fm3̅m space group, consists of tetrahedral and octahedral cages with an fcu topology ().

elements.content: Postsynthetic modification of UiO-67-SO 2 F (1) via SuFEx and single-crystal X-ray structures of extended framework of UiO-67-SO 2 F and its modified UiO-67s. For details on the X-ray structures, see the Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text: 1  Postsynthetic modification of UiO-67-SO  2  F (1) via SuFEx and single-crystal X-ray structures of extended framework of UiO-67-SO  2  F and its modified UiO-67s. For details on the X-ray structures, see the Supporting Information.

elements.content: The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of 1 was also consistent with the simulated pattern generated from its single crystal X-ray structure (). The crystallinity of 1 was maintained, as evidenced by PXRD and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data even after heating the crystals of 1 up to 350 °C (Figure S3). The gas sorption experiment with N2 at 77 K clearly demonstrated that 1 shows the same isotherm I as its parent, UiO-67. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area of 1 was measured to afford 1572 m2 g–1 (). The smaller surface area of 1 than that of the parent UiO-67 was due to the presence of the bulky sulfonyl fluoride group in the linker.
elements.clean_text: The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of 1 was also consistent with the simulated pattern generated from its single crystal X-ray structure (). The crystallinity of 1 was maintained, as evidenced by PXRD and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data even after heating the crystals of 1 up to 350 °C (Figure S3). The gas sorption experiment with N2 at 77 K clearly demonstrated that 1 shows the same isotherm I as its parent, UiO-67. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of 1 was measured to afford 1572 m2 g-1 (). The smaller surface area of 1 than that of the parent UiO-67 was due to the presence of the bulky sulfonyl fluoride group in the linker.

elements.content: To achieve SuFEx-based PSM from 1, we treated methoxytrimethylsilane (TMS–OMe), 1-methyl-3-(2-(trimethylsilyloxy)­ethyl)-1H-imidazolium bromide ([TMSO–R1]­Br), 2-((trimethylsilyl)­oxy)­pyridine (TMSO–R2), bis­(trimethylsilyl)­amine (TMS–NHR3), and 2-((tert-butoxycarbonyl)­amino)-3-((trimethylsilyl)­oxy)­propanoic acid (N-Boc-O-TMS-L-serine, TMSO–R4) as PSM partners of 1 in MeCN ( and the Supporting Information) to produce UiO-67-SO 3 Me (2), UiO-67-SO 3 R 1 Br (3), UiO-67-SO 3 R 2 (4), UiO-67-SO 2 NHR 3 (5), and UiO-67-SO 3 R 4 (6), respectively. The silylated compounds were prepared within 2 steps by the silylation in good yields (see the Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text: To achieve SuFEx-based PSM from 1, we treated methoxytrimethylsilane (TMS-OMe), 1-methyl-3-(2-(trimethylsilyloxy)ethyl)-1H-imidazolium bromide ([TMSO-R1]Br), 2-((trimethylsilyl)oxy)pyridine (TMSO-R2), bis(trimethylsilyl)amine (TMS-NHR3), and 2-((tert-butoxycarbonyl)amino)-3-((trimethylsilyl)oxy)propanoic acid (N-Boc-O-TMS-L-serine, TMSO-R4) as PSM partners of 1 in MeCN ( and the Supporting Information) to produce UiO-67-SO  3  Me (2), UiO-67-SO  3  R  1  Br (3), UiO-67-SO  3  R  2  (4), UiO-67-SO  2  NHR  3  (5), and UiO-67-SO  3  R  4  (6), respectively. The silylated compounds were prepared within 2 steps by the silylation in good yields (see the Supporting Information).

elements.content: We confirmed the SuFEx in MOFs with the generation of trimethylsilylfluoride (TMS–F) by 1H- and 19F-NMR spectroscopy ( and Figures S5 and S6). As the reaction proceeds, the small 1H NMR signals corresponding to TMS–F appear at the room temperature after 3 h. When the reaction temperature was raised up to 50 °C to push the SuFEx reaction, the doublet peak at 0.21 ppm of TMS–F was increased in 1H NMR spectroscopy. In addition, the singlet peak at −157 ppm corresponding to TMS–F was also confirmed by 19F-NMR spectroscopy. Finally, the reaction was completed within 48 h without the base catalyst.
elements.clean_text: We confirmed the SuFEx in MOFs with the generation of trimethylsilylfluoride (TMS-F) by 1H- and 19F-NMR spectroscopy ( and Figures S5 and S6). As the reaction proceeds, the small 1H NMR signals corresponding to TMS-F appear at the room temperature after 3 h. When the reaction temperature was raised up to 50 °C to push the SuFEx reaction, the doublet peak at 0.21 ppm of TMS-F was increased in 1H NMR spectroscopy. In addition, the singlet peak at -157 ppm corresponding to TMS-F was also confirmed by 19F-NMR spectroscopy. Finally, the reaction was completed within 48 h without the base catalyst.

elements.content: Reaction monitoring of SuFEx with TMSOR1Br in (a) 1H NMR/CD3CN and (b) 19F-NMR/CD3CN.
elements.clean_text: 4  Reaction monitoring of SuFEx with TMSOR1Br in (a) 1H NMR/CD3CN and (b) 19F-NMR/CD3CN.

elements.content: The PXRD patterns of five postsynthetically modified MOFs were also retained compared to 1 (). Furthermore, single crystals of 1 were converted into the functionalized MOFs without losing single crystallinity confirming that the SuFEx-based PSM can be carried out. The SuFEx-PSM of 1 was also confirmed by the SXRD studies of the products (). The postsynthetically modified MOFs were digested with a 50% aqueous HF and subsequently the solution was analyzed by 1H NMR spectroscopy to confirm that the SuFEx-based PSM was successfully carried out as the fluoride of the ligand was replaced (Figures S7–S11). According to the digestion analysis, conversion yields of 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6 were 85, 99, 99, 84, and 63%, respectively. Furthermore, the only byproduct, TMS–F, could be removed during simple washing and drying under vacuum at room temperature (Figures S7–S11).
elements.clean_text: The PXRD patterns of five postsynthetically modified MOFs were also retained compared to 1 (). Furthermore, single crystals of 1 were converted into the functionalized MOFs without losing single crystallinity confirming that the SuFEx-based PSM can be carried out. The SuFEx-PSM of 1 was also confirmed by the SXRD studies of the products (). The postsynthetically modified MOFs were digested with a 50% aqueous HF and subsequently the solution was analyzed by 1H NMR spectroscopy to confirm that the SuFEx-based PSM was successfully carried out as the fluoride of the ligand was replaced (Figures S7-S11). According to the digestion analysis, conversion yields of 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6 were 85, 99, 99, 84, and 63%, respectively. Furthermore, the only byproduct, TMS-F, could be removed during simple washing and drying under vacuum at room temperature (Figures S7-S11).

elements.content: The gas sorption experiment with N2 at 77 K was carried out to evaluate the porosity of postsynthetically modified MOFs after the SuFEx-based PSM. The BET surface areas of 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6 were decreased to 1510, 1077, 1311, 1556, and 1044 m2 g–1, respectively corresponding to the conversion yields and the bulkier substituents rather than fluoride (). Furthermore, according to the gas sorption experiment, it showed the porous structures were also well-retained after SuFEx.
elements.clean_text: The gas sorption experiment with N2 at 77 K was carried out to evaluate the porosity of postsynthetically modified MOFs after the SuFEx-based PSM. The BET surface areas of 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6 were decreased to 1510, 1077, 1311, 1556, and 1044 m2 g-1, respectively corresponding to the conversion yields and the bulkier substituents rather than fluoride (). Furthermore, according to the gas sorption experiment, it showed the porous structures were also well-retained after SuFEx.

elements.content: Among various applications of imidazolium functionalized MOFs such as proton conductivities, postsynthetic transition-metal complexation, and catalysis, examples of organocatalysis using imidazolium functionalized MOFs as N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) catalysts are rare. Thus, we decided to explore the use of 3 as a heterogeneous catalyst for the benzoin condensation reaction (). Before the reaction, 3 was activated by treatment with potassium tert-butoxide (KO t Bu) as a base for 30 min. The activated 3 successfully catalyzed the transformation of benzaldehyde to benzoin, whereas its crystallinity was retained after the catalysis (, entry 3, and Figure S2). However, 1 did not show any conversion of benzaldehyde to benzoin under the same reaction conditions. Interestingly, the in situ generation of free NHC from HOR1Br did not show full conversion of benzaldehyde (, entry 2), as the free NHC generated from HOR1Br easily decomposes and loses its catalytic activity presumably due to its pendent hydroxyl functional group. The recyclability of 3 as a heterogeneous catalyst was also confirmed (entry 4).
elements.clean_text: Among various applications of imidazolium functionalized MOFs such as proton conductivities, postsynthetic transition-metal complexation, and catalysis, examples of organocatalysis using imidazolium functionalized MOFs as N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) catalysts are rare. Thus, we decided to explore the use of 3 as a heterogeneous catalyst for the benzoin condensation reaction (). Before the reaction, 3 was activated by treatment with potassium tert-butoxide (KO t Bu) as a base for 30 min. The activated 3 successfully catalyzed the transformation of benzaldehyde to benzoin, whereas its crystallinity was retained after the catalysis (, entry 3, and Figure S2). However, 1 did not show any conversion of benzaldehyde to benzoin under the same reaction conditions. Interestingly, the in situ generation of free NHC from HOR1Br did not show full conversion of benzaldehyde (, entry 2), as the free NHC generated from HOR1Br easily decomposes and loses its catalytic activity presumably due to its pendent hydroxyl functional group. The recyclability of 3 as a heterogeneous catalyst was also confirmed (entry 4).

Benzoin Condensation Using <bold>UiO-67-SO</bold> <sub> <bold>3</bold> </sub> <bold>R</bold> <sub> <bold>1</bold> </sub> <bold>Br</bold> (<bold>3</bold>) entry condition (equiv) yield (%) 1 UiO-67-SO 2 F (0.1), KO t Bu (0.1) 0 2 HOR 1 Br (0.1), KO t Bu (0.1) 75 3 UiO-67-SO 3 R 1 Br (0.1), KO t Bu (0.1) 99 4 2nd/3rd cycle 99

The yield was determined by 1H NMR.

In summary, we have demonstrated that the new type of click reaction, SuFEx, can be employed a versatile tool for PSM of MOFs. To illustrate the principle, a UiO-67 type MOF with a sulfonyl fluoride group was successfully synthesized for the first time. Various functional groups were introduced into the MOF via SuFEx, which has been characterized by various analytical methods. Furthermore, the PSM can be achieved selectively for the sulfonyl fluoride (R-SO2F) without degrading the MOF structure as confirmed by single crystal X-ray diffraction methods. We believe that the present platform, SuFExable MOF, provides a new route to introduce useful functional groups inside MOFs by PSM. In particular, natural compounds with hydroxyl or amine groups, such as amino acids, sugars, and proteins, can be introduced into this platform via SuFEx click chemistry. Furthermore, this SuFEx-based PSMs can be extended to other MOFs. Work along this line is in progress.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have demonstrated that the new type of click reaction, SuFEx, can be employed a versatile tool for PSM of MOFs. To illustrate the principle, a UiO-67 type MOF with a sulfonyl fluoride group was successfully synthesized for the first time. Various functional groups were introduced into the MOF via SuFEx, which has been characterized by various analytical methods. Furthermore, the PSM can be achieved selectively for the sulfonyl fluoride (R-SO2F) without degrading the MOF structure as confirmed by single crystal X-ray diffraction methods. We believe that the present platform, SuFExable MOF, provides a new route to introduce useful functional groups inside MOFs by PSM. In particular, natural compounds with hydroxyl or amine groups, such as amino acids, sugars, and proteins, can be introduced into this platform via SuFEx click chemistry. Furthermore, this SuFEx-based PSMs can be extended to other MOFs. Work along this line is in progress.

cln_elements.content:
The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of 1 was also consistent with the simulated pattern generated from its single crystal X-ray structure (). The crystallinity of 1 was maintained, as evidenced by PXRD and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data even after heating the crystals of 1 up to 350 °C (Figure S3). The gas sorption experiment with N2 at 77 K clearly demonstrated that 1 shows the same isotherm I as its parent, UiO-67. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area of 1 was measured to afford 1572 m2 g–1 (). The smaller surface area of 1 than that of the parent UiO-67 was due to the presence of the bulky sulfonyl fluoride group in the linker.

The gas sorption experiment with N2 at 77 K was carried out to evaluate the porosity of postsynthetically modified MOFs after the SuFEx-based PSM. The BET surface areas of 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6 were decreased to 1510, 1077, 1311, 1556, and 1044 m2 g–1, respectively corresponding to the conversion yields and the bulkier substituents rather than fluoride (). Furthermore, according to the gas sorption experiment, it showed the porous structures were also well-retained after SuFEx.

a. The yield was determined by 1H NMR.

Postsynthetic modification of UiO-67-SO 2 F (1) via SuFEx and single-crystal X-ray structures of extended framework of UiO-67-SO 2 F and its modified UiO-67s. For details on the X-ray structures, see the Supporting Information.
